page.title: 13FILKINS: TERRAIN/BUILDINGS
page.content: Limestone downs and valleys cover most of this block in the Cotswolds. The R. Leach and water from Filkins Springs drain south to the nearby Thames Val- ley. The water at Eastleach and Filkins ensured early settlement there. Traces of wooden round huts and Saxon burial grounds have been found at Filkins but only hints of medieval buildings now remain. The pattern of closes for en- closing animals at night, and open commons, can still be seen. Almost all the standing buildings are of stone quarried within the block. Stone for field and house walling, and fine 'for- est marble' for slate roofs and paving are all to be found. From the 17TH CENTURY, 6 houses have been listed as noteworthy, and also a fine three- storey mill house with hipped roof. We identify about 12 cottages of the period which are similar in size.
